What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: ability to speak and articulate my thoughts, knowledge about global finance
Answer filled out under MGMT582 already. Great breadth of topics for this class.

I really gained a better understanding of the global financial system, of the impacts that the financial crisis has had on development and the future governmental and regulatory challenges. I also learned about important technological innovations like the Blockchain, Bitcoin and Crowdfunding.

Learned a lot more about how the global financial system works and might work in the future, on a big picture level; was not aware of the level of connectivity and inter-reliance, which was not fully addressed in previous international economics courses.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: too much credit for participation while assignments are not given proper credit
strengths- broad-based, covered a lot of material weaknesses- classes could have been more structured

I really enjoyed our homework assignments. I got to read and listen to incredibly interesting people and positions in a variety of important areas of global finance. I enjoyed the class discussions a lot and hope that they can be slightly more interactive in the future.

The strength of the course was the assigned material and interviews, which were very interesting and mind expanding. The weakness was perhaps in the structure of the class discussion. The assignments provoked deeper understanding, and I thoroughly enjoyed thinking about points made by Professor Garten in his lectures. However, the design of class discussion seemed less effective. Students seemed to have incentive to speak before thinking, based on pressure for the participation requirement and the size of the class. Discussion points tended (not always) to resemble the form of "what are your thoughts on ___." It seemed that students had more incentive to say anything than to take time to form though-provoking responses, as waiting to do so meant you were less likely to be called on. However, this might be unavoidable in larger SOM classes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes if you want to know more about global finance in a general way
Absolutely. It gives a very good overview over the global financial system and how it has changed since the financial crisis.
